titleInfo.title: LSU History Oral History Project: Faculty & Adminstrators
titleInfo.subTitle: Virginia Hamilton Vercher oral history interview, 1992-1993.

name.description: Virginia Hamilton Vercher was born in York County near Fort Mill, South Carolina, on January 8, 1922. She attended high school and two years of college, then worked for six years at Duke Power Company. She moved to Louisiana with her husband, a Shreveport native who worked for Ethyl Corporation in Baton Rouge. She worked for the Louisiana State Department of Revenue for four years, and after becoming pregnant, spent the next six years as a stay-at-home mom. She started working for Louisiana State University in 1962 as a secretary to Dr. James Upp, Director of Agriculture Experiment Stations, and she continued to work for Upp's successor, Doyle Chambers. She became the secretary to Chancellor Cecil Taylor in 1966, and shortly thereafter, was asked by Bernard Sliger to set up a Personnel Services office at LSU's Baton Rouge campus. Vercher retired as Associate Director of Personnel Services in 1983. She passed away in 1997.

mods.abstract: Vercher recalls her experiences working in various administrative secretarial positions and the Personnel Services office at LSU in the 1960s though 1980s. Prompted by Besch, who also often shares his opinions, Vercher offers personal impressions and memories of various administrators, deans, and professors at LSU. She describes the development of the Personnel Services office and her role as the founding employee. She recalls the roles and duties of key campus administrators including Cecil Taylor, Bernard Sliger, Paul Murrill, Lynn Pesson and James Reddoch among others. Vercher goes into detail on university policies and procedures on tenure, academic and non-academic appointments, classified and unclassified positions, job titles, salary levels, personnel forms, biographical data on employees, and many other topics.
